title: `entityIds` validation causes `OutOfMemoryError`
stack_trace: Here is an example of such a failure - https://github.com/hashgraph/hedera-state-validator/actions/runs/21646954511/job/62401464000
Error: Exception in thread "JNA Cleaner" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space

title: Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: oracle/xdb/XMLType
stack_trace: For my rml config running `docker run ... rmlio/rmlmapper-java:v8.0.0` (Oracle DB) fails with the following:

I first suspected this had to with Oracle licensing, that prohibits adding the required dependency directly (see issue https://github.com/RMLio/rmlmapper-java/issues/146#issuecomment-1032825946 for example). However, going by the Readme this issue [has been resolved since v6.1.0](https://github.com/RMLio/rmlmapper-java/commit/fc83894306dafce32613ef3c239efc1996d36ba4#diff-b335630551682c19a781afebcf4d07bf978fb1f8ac04c6bf87428ed5106870f5L158-L177).
After some more investigation I added the `xdb6` jarfile. This makes my setup run as it's supposed to!

From my experience I cannot judge if adding `xdb6` always is a hard requirement when using RML on an Oracle DB, or if it is specific to my case. Mainly flagging here in case this rings a bell to maintainers, in which case adding a notice about this in the readme would be a good improvement.

title: IllegalStateException: Invalid entity reference! in Recover Arrows
stack_trace: ## 🐛 Issue: `IllegalStateException: Invalid entity reference!` in Recover Arrows
The server regularly crashes in the WorldThread due to an invalid entity reference (`Invalid entity reference!`) within the `ArrowMagnetSystem` of **Recover Arrows**.
The error occurs when the plugin attempts to access an arrow entity that has already been removed.
1. Start the server with Recover Arrows enabled
3. After some time (or with a large number of arrows), the crash occurs in the world thread.
The bug seems to occur more frequently when:
The plugin should detect and clean up invalid entity references **without** crashing the server.
The server throws an `IllegalStateException` and stops the WorldThread.
The plugin stores `Ref` objects for arrows and later attempts to access them **even though the entity has already been removed**.
When `Store.removeEntity(...)` is executed, the `Ref` becomes invalid—however, the plugin does not check for this before `store.getComponent(ref)`.
* Alternatively: Store the entity ID and resolve it again as needed
* Or react to entity removal events and proactively delete references.

title: Fetching manifest from ECR fails due to missing Docker-Content-Digest header
stack_trace: ### NullPointerException when fetching manifest from ECR
I am attempting to fetch an Manifest for a container image, and it is throwing a NullPointerException. I've reproduced this with a public ECR image here.

Debugging through the code I found that the `getDescriptor` call inside `getManifest` populates the digest based on the `Docker-Content-Digest` header value, which ECR doesn't seem to return. This results in the `ManifestDescriptor.of` call in `getManifest` to fail with the digest not null assertion at the beginning. Seems like the only headers its returning are,

In this particular case, I already know the digest as well, as I've passed it in as part of the `ContainerRef` which probably can be set using that, but then it would be problematic if this is called with a container ref without a digest. Maybe if digest doesn't get returned, it could do a probe request to get the digest if the container ref doesn't have the digest in it?

title: Pulling multi-arch image index fails incorrect validation
stack_trace: I am attempting to fetch an attached artifact via the Java SDK give the image name and tag.
For example, I have a change log attached to the image coordinates in the repo with type 'application/vnd.demo.changelog'
I want to fetch the change log file from my deployment tooling (which is in Java) give the image, in this case `myrepo.local/jenkins-uat/demo/webapp:1.0.0`

My approach for doing this is to get the Index from `registry.getIndex()` for the multi arch image `myrepo.local/jenkins-uat/demo/webapp:1.0.0` is pointing to, then find the digest of the first nested manifest, and use that to call `registry.getReferrers()` which requires a digest to find the artifact I need.
However this failed at the first step of getting the index with this:
Based on the [OCI image spec for image index](https://github.com/opencontainers/image-spec/blob/main/image-index.md) manifest, the manifest looks like this.

This does not have a `digest` field at the top of the JSON document, however the code in `getIndex()` method in `Registry` tries to [parse this manifest](https://github.com/oras-project/oras-java/blob/f248237a8d6936dedc88caf983b76ba07c20dce5/src/main/java/land/oras/Registry.java#L564) via `ManifestDescriptor.of(...)` which [checks to see if there's a digest](https://github.com/oras-project/oras-java/blob/main/src/main/java/land/oras/ManifestDescriptor.java#L191) which does not exist.
Seems like `getIndex()` response requiring a `digest` seems incorrect. It could be that my approach for getting to the referrers is incorrect? If so appreciate any help in how it should be done.

title: Server code generation requires protocol implementations from dependencies to be used in services
stack_trace: Server protocol implementations that are added as dependencies to a Smithy Java project are expected to be used in the project's services. Not using them results in exceptions being thrown. For example, when depending on `restJson1` and `rpcv2Cbor` but only using `rpcv2Cbor` in a service:
Exception in thread "main" java.util.NoSuchElementException: Expected trait not found: software.amazon.smithy.java.core.schema.TraitKey
I'm not sure if this is limited to server code generation only.

To reproduce this behavior, clone [smithy-examples](https://github.com/smithy-lang/smithy-examples), remove `restJson1` from the [Smithy Kotlin example service](https://github.com/smithy-lang/smithy-examples/blob/26e410d48369413babb0c02c9aad79d47f51ec9f/smithy-kotlin-examples/quickstart-kotlin/smithy/model/main.smithy#L12) (Notice that [both protocols are still in the server dependencies](https://github.com/smithy-lang/smithy-examples/blob/26e410d48369413babb0c02c9aad79d47f51ec9f/smithy-kotlin-examples/quickstart-kotlin/server/build.gradle.kts#L20-L23)), then run `./gradlew  :quickstart-kotlin:server:run`.
If this is expected behavior then feel free to close the issue.

title: Fix: Auto-reconnect not triggered on ping timeout - NodeTimeoutException not caught
stack_trace: The automatic reconnection mechanism is not being triggered when ping requests timeout, causing the application to remain in a disconnected state until a manual reconnection is performed.
When ping requests fail with `NodeTimeoutException`, the exception is not caught properly in `IqStreamNodeHandler.sendPing()`. The method only catches `SessionClosedException`, which means:
2. The exception is printed to console but not handled
3. The `schedulePing()` method never receives `null` as return value
4. The automatic reconnect condition `if(result == null)` is never true
5. Ping scheduling continues indefinitely without triggering reconnection

Exception in thread "ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-3" com.github.auties00.cobalt.exception.NodeTimeoutException: Node[description=iq, attributes={to=s.whatsapp.net, xmlns=w:p, type=get, id=C47E6EC8FF}, children=[Node[description=ping]]]
When a ping request times out, the system should:
The catch block only handles `SessionClosedException`, but `whatsapp.sendNode()` can also throw `NodeTimeoutException` when the 60-second timeout expires in `SocketRequest.waitForResponse()`.
Add `NodeTimeoutException` to the catch block to properly handle ping timeouts:
1. When `sendPing()` returns `null`, the `schedulePing()` method will detect it
4. The `disconnect()` method with `RECONNECTING` reason automatically calls `connect(reason)` at the end
5. A fresh connection is established with proper cleanup of pending requests
- This is a minimal, surgical fix that addresses the immediate issue
- No changes to the reconnection logic or timing are needed
- The existing 30-second ping interval and 60-second timeout remain appropriate
- Manual reconnection via `whatsapp.reconnect()` works because it forces the same cleanup/reconnect flow
- **Before:** Application requires manual intervention when ping timeouts occur
- **After:** Application automatically recovers from ping timeouts without user intervention
- **Risk:** Very low - only adds one exception type to an existing catch block

title: Fix NPE
Add --add-opens java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED to code generator and quarkus update tool
stack_trace: During review of https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/pull/47637 it has been determined that quarkus users running on JDK 24 and later will see certain stack traces for code samples when running tests. Example:
[INFO] Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 0.898 s -- in org.acme.GreetingResourceTest

Exception in thread "vert.x-internal-blocking-1" java.lang.IllegalAccessError: module java.base does not open java.lang to unnamed module @345d053b; to use the thread-local-reset capability on Java 24 or later, use this JVM option: --add-opens java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED
Exception in thread "executor-thread-1" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: Could not initialize class org.jboss.threads.JDKSpecific$ThreadAccess

Caused by: java.lang.ExceptionInInitializerError: Exception java.lang.IllegalAccessError: module java.base does not open java.lang to unnamed module @345d053b; to use the thread-local-reset capability on Java 24 or later, use this JVM option: --add-opens java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED [in thread "vert.x-internal-blocking-1"]
The reason for this is that jboss-threads version `3.9.1` and newer uses some JDK internals reflectively and recent JDKs throw `IllegalAccessError` in those cases.

Therefore, the code generators hosted at https://code.quarkus.io/ need to get updated to include the `--add-opens` clauses similar to what #47637 did for quarkus core. Something similar needs to happen for the quarkus update tool when users upgrade from 3.22 to newer versions.

title: [BUG] Error thrown when Spotify API rate limit has been exceeded
stack_trace: When a Spotify link of a song or a playlist is passed to Drifty CLI/GUI, it tries to retrieve the filename but fails with an uncaught exception. Drifty GUI keeps on indicating that the filename retrieval process is ongoing.
The error stack trace visible in the terminal is provided below:

Exception in thread "Thread-11" com.google.gson.JsonSyntaxException: com.google.gson.stream.MalformedJsonException: Use JsonReader.setStrictness(Strictness.LENIENT) to accept malformed JSON at line 1 column 6 path $
Caused by: com.google.gson.stream.MalformedJsonException: Use JsonReader.setStrictness(Strictness.LENIENT) to accept malformed JSON at line 1 column 6 path $
3. If rate has been exceeded for your machine, an exception will be thrown and is visible in the terminal.
Once the API rate exceeds, Drifty can show proper error message with an actionable task something like "retry after 1 hour or 24 hours".
**Drifty CLI throwing the stack trace of the error**
**Stack trace thrown by error in Drifty GUI**
I found out that the error occurs because the `playlistMetadataResponseBody` is `Too many requests` (which is not a JSON thus causing the error) when the Spotify API exceeds rate limit.
This string must be checked before JSON parser parses it, to fix this issue.

title: Spring webmvc does not catch exception
stack_trace: I have recently upgraded to spring boot 4.0.0, where I use `spring-boot-starter-webmvc`. Found a strange behavior which I believe is a bug.

I have a controller, in which I called make a service call to a server, which has an expired certificate. However, the exception trace is shown on the server log, but the `ExceptionHandler` did not catch it. So, the client, i.e., the webapplication eventually gets a timeout exception instead of the actual cause. (The exception trace is shown in the end).

What is interesting is that I have another controller in the same app calling the same server of a different service. That call's exception is handled by the `ExceptionHandler` and returned back to the user. The Exception objects for both call are of the same class. Hence, this baffles me. The stack trace seems to suggests one of the service is called on a different thread (I guess). But all these service calls are synchronous and no where have I implemented asynchronous call or starting a new thread. I would think this is a bug?

title: Actuator /info endpoint fails in Java 25 Native Image (VirtualThreadSchedulerMXBean support)
stack_trace: I am encountering an issue when running a Spring Boot 4.0.1 application built as a GraalVM Native Image using Java 25.

When accessing the `/actuator/info` endpoint, the application throws a `HttpMessageNotWritableException`. The root cause is an `IllegalArgumentException` stating that `jdk.management.VirtualThreadSchedulerMXBean` is not a platform management interface.

This occurs despite the recent changes in **PR #43594**, which added `ProcessInfoContributorRuntimeHints` to register this class for reflection. It appears that while the class is reflectively available, the `ManagementFactory` in the native image environment does not recognize it as a valid Platform MXBean.
I have created a minimal reproducer repository.
The request fails with a 500 Internal Server Error. The logs show:
2026-01-13T14:25:44.338+01:00 ERROR ... 500 Server Error for HTTP GET "/actuator/info"
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: jdk.management.VirtualThreadSchedulerMXBean is not a platform management interface

The feature was introduced in **PR #43594**, which added the `getVirtualThreads()` method to `ProcessInfo` and included `ProcessInfoContributorRuntimeHints` to register `jdk.management.VirtualThreadSchedulerMXBean` for reflection.

However, the exception comes from `ManagementFactory.getPlatformMXBean(Class)`, which validates if the requested class is a known platform MXBean. In a standard JVM, this works for `VirtualThreadSchedulerMXBean` in Java 24/25. In the Native Image (SubstrateVM), it seems this new MXBean is not automatically registered in the internal management support lookup, or `ManagementFactory` requires specific GraalVM configuration/substitution to recognize it, beyond just standard reflection hints.
* `--enable-monitoring=all`: Applied, but did not resolve the issue.
* `RuntimeHints`: The existing hints from PR #43594 are present, but do not satisfy the `ManagementFactory` check.

title: Adminclient.sh crash when sleeper.tags property is malformed
stack_trace: When using the adminClient to modify the `sleeper.tags` property. If the value is malformed and doesn't contain a correct number of commas, then the client crashes with an obscure exception message.
4. Modify `sleeper.tags` to have an malformed entry like key=value instead of key,value.
The admin client should not crash when the tags property is invalid or unreadable.

You should see in the admin client that the property value is invalid, the same as if you had set an invalid value for any other property. This screen includes the property description. It should be clear from the property description why your value is invalid.

The problem seems to be that the tags are parsed whenever we read the instance properties. If they can't be parsed, we can't create the InstanceProperties object. We could ignore that failure during creation of the object. The InstanceProperties.getTags method could throw an exception if the tags could not be read.
We should then be able to validate the resulting InstanceProperties object to get the expected validation failure.

To help understand the admin client, some relevant places to look are `UpdatePropertiesRequest.getInvalidProperties`, where we check for invalid properties, and `PropertiesDiff.print`, where we display the failure to the user. We won't need to change the code in these places. The problem for this issue is that the admin client never gets to that code, because it crashes when the InstanceProperties object is created.

We can cover this behaviour in InstancePropertiesTest. We can call `InstanceProperties.createWithoutValidation` with an invalid value for the tags property. We can assert that an exception is only thrown when you call `InstanceProperties.validate`. We can also assert that it should fail when you try to read the tags when they're invalid.

title: Rapid execution of the `/god` command
stack_trace: What version of EliteEssentials are you running?
- Version: `Unknown (based on stack trace, likely contains bug in HytaleGodCommand.java:86)`
What version of Hytale is this happening on?

Rapid execution of the `/god` command (3+ times within seconds) causes a critical failure in the Entity Component System (ECS). The plugin attempts to remove an `Invulnerable` component that doesn't exist in the player's entity archetype, corrupting the entity's data structure. This leads to a cascade of `IndexOutOfBoundsException` errors across multiple systems (emote plugin, block health system, etc.), ultimately crashing the world thread and forcing the world to shutdown.
Steps to make the bug happen again:
1. Grant a player permission to use `/god` and `/gm` commands
2. Have the player execute `/god` command rapidly 3+ times within 2-3 seconds
3. Immediately follow with `/gm c` and `/gm a` commands
5. Observe server logs for the chain of exceptions and world crash

The `/god` command should safely toggle invulnerability status regardless of execution frequency, without corrupting entity data or affecting other systems. Subsequent commands should execute normally.
Let us know what troubleshooting steps you've done.
- Restarted the server (required after world crash)
- Verified command permissions are correctly set
- Checked that no other conflicting god-mode plugins are installed
- Monitored server logs for error patterns
Please include anything that helps us understand the problem better:
[2026/01/28 16:12:46 SEVERE] [AbstractCommand] Exception while running that command:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: ComponentType is not in archetype: ComponentType{... typeClass=...Invulnerable, index=23}
[2026/01/28 16:12:46 SEVERE] [Hytale] Exception in thread Thread[#110,WorldThread - default,5,...]:
- **Other plugins installed:** Emote plugin (`com._056.emote.DoubleTapDetector`) - also affected by the corruption
- **Trigger pattern:** The issue consistently occurs with rapid command execution, suggesting a race condition or state synchronization problem
- **Impact:** World-wide crash affecting all players in the instance
- **Workaround:** Currently advising players to use `/god` command with at least 2-3 second intervals between uses
- **Environment:** Multiplayer server with ECS-based entity system (Hytale's component architecture)

**Root Cause Analysis:** The `HytaleGodCommand.execute()` method at line 86 calls `removeComponent()` on an entity's `Invulnerable` component without verifying the component's existence in the current archetype. When commands are executed rapidly, the entity's state may change between checks, leading to attempts to remove non-existent components and corrupting the ECS indices.

title: GLTF extensions: KHR_mesh_quantization
stack_trace: Would be a great help if **KHR_mesh_quantization** is implemented in gdx-gltf.
To take full advantage of gltfpack from MeshOptimizer library you need **KHR_mesh_quantization**.  Also **EXT_mesh_gpu_instancing** extention support would be helpful.
Exception when trying to use optimized gltf files:
Exception in thread "main" net.mgsx.gltf.loaders.exceptions.GLTFUnsupportedException: Extension KHR_mesh_quantization required but not supported

gltfpack substantially changes the glTF data by optimizing the meshes for vertex fetch and transform cache, quantizing the geometry to reduce the memory consumption and size, merging meshes to reduce the draw call count, quantizing and resampling animations to reduce animation size and simplify playback, and pruning the node tree by removing or collapsing redundant nodes. It will also simplify the meshes when requested to do so.

By default gltfpack outputs regular .glb/.gltf files that have been optimized for GPU consumption using various cache optimizers and quantization. These files can be loaded by GLTF loaders that support **KHR_mesh_quantization** extension such as [three.js](https://threejs.org/) (r111+) and [Babylon.js](https://www.babylonjs.com/) (4.1+).

title: None UTF-8 character in Custom Properties [MPSat] preventing load
stack_trace: Whilst writing a Custom Property, STG Reachability Analysis, I entered a non UTF-8 character "¬" without realising. I updated the property, and then ran the property. I received an error message when running, similar to the standard error you receive when entering in correct syntax of the Reach language.
After this you're unable to open the Custom Property panel, receiving the following error message in the Problems output:
Exception in thread "AWT-EventQueue-0" java.lang.RuntimeException: com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.io.MalformedByteSequenceException: Invalid byte 1 of 1-byte UTF-8 sequence.
When you go into the xml file where the Custom Properties are store and remove the character this fixes the problem and you're able to open the Custom Property panel again.
It's also worth mentioning if you don't update the property and just run it with the character in the problem doesn't happen, only when properties are saved.

Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: C:\Users\miche\code-with-quarkus\code-with-quarkus\kotlin\build\classes\java\main does not exist
Create a class `src/main/java/Dummy.java` in every Kotlin-only module.
The underlying problem is probably that Quarkus expects the folder of every source set reported by the Gradle application model to exist, but it doesn't have to.

title: GROBID 0.8.1 Docker Container Fails Due to cgroup v2 NullPointerException on MacOS
stack_trace: I'm trying to use GROBID via Docker to extract content from PDF files, but the container fails to start due to an error related to cgroup version issues.

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "jdk.internal.platform.CgroupInfo.getMountPoint()" because "anyController" is null

It appears that Grobid (or its underlying JVM/Dropwizard setup) is trying to access cgroup data that isn’t present in my environment, which uses cgroups v2 by default. I understand that many new machines have cgroups v2 while older setups might use v1, but I'm not sure how to make Grobid work correctly under this configuration.

Could you please advise on how to run Grobid via Docker on a system with cgroups v2 (MacOS Ventura, OpenJDK 11)? Is there a recommended workaround or configuration change that might help avoid this NullPointerException?

title: PackageNotInstalledException when parsing requirements.txt with indented comments
stack_trace: The PythonControllerBase.getDependenciesImpl() method fails to parse requirements.txt with indented comments, throwing a PackageNotInstalledException with error messages like:
Package name=># via matplotlib is not installed on your python environment
The bug is in PythonControllerBase.java:156 where the code filters out comment lines:
// BUG: Only filters lines starting with '#', misses indented comments

The filter misses lines starting with whitespace + #, treating them as package names. When getDependencyName("    # via matplotlib") is called, it returns # via matplotlib, which causes the installation failure.

Exception in thread "main" io.github.guacsec.trustifyda.exception.PackageNotInstalledException: Package name=># via matplotlib is not installed on your python environment, either install it ( better to install requirements.txt altogether) or turn on environment variable TRUSTIFY_DA_PYTHON_VIRTUAL_ENV=true to automatically install it on virtual environment (will slow down the analysis)

title: SnakeYAML crashes on lambda/synthetic class fields in Utensils.yamlString
stack_trace: Calling `Utensils.yamlString()` on a generated expression object (e.g. `arb.functions.G`) throws a `YAMLException` when SnakeYAML encounters lambda/synthetic class instances stored in fields (e.g. from `NAryOperationNode`).
Exception in thread "main" org.yaml.snakeyaml.error.YAMLException: No JavaBean properties found in arb.expressions.nodes.nary.NAryOperationNode$$Lambda/0x0000000046135ac0

SnakeYAML's `Representer` tries to introspect lambda instances as JavaBeans. Lambdas (synthetic classes) have no bean properties, so `PropertyUtils.getPropertiesMap` throws. This happens when traversing object graphs that contain fields holding references to lambda instances, such as those generated by `NAryOperationNode`.
The current `TypeRepresenter` does not handle synthetic/lambda classes.
* A custom {@link Representer} implementation for serializing various Arb4j
* types into YAML. This class ensures that objects are serialized efficiently
* using SnakeYAML's automatic anchoring and aliasing mechanism, while allowing
* for custom representations of specific types such as {@link Real},
Override `representJavaBeanProperty` in `TypeRepresenter` to skip synthetic (lambda) class instances:
This goes directly into the existing `TypeRepresenter` class. No new class needed.

title: Jandex fails when indexing another Kotlin-generated class
stack_trace: When compiled with kotlinc 2.2.20, the following program contains an invalid type annotation that causes jandex to crash:
private fun f(foo: Int, bar: Int) {}
The output contains incorrect `TYPE_ARGUMENT` indices. I think that `@ParameterName` annotations associated wtih `f` are incorrectly getting propagated to `b`:
private final kotlin.reflect.KFunction<kotlin.Unit> b(kotlin.jvm.functions.Function1<? super E, kotlin.Unit>);
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.IllegalStateException: Type annotation referred to a type argument that does not exist

I'm going to see about reporting this against kotlinc and hopefully getting it fixed in future versions, but similar to https://github.com/smallrye/jandex/issues/284, it might make sense for jandex to handle this case leniently.

title: bug: content-type: application/json; charset=utf-8 is rejected by smithy-clients
stack_trace: When testing generated clients on some of non-aws services they sometimes respond with content-type header: `application/json; charset=utf-8`. The deserialization fails as smithy clients don't recognize that the content-type is still `application/json`.
Granted `charset=utf-8` seems redundant for JSON, though I don't think smithy java clients should fail deserialization if charset option is specified.
Here's an exception that I observed:

Exception in thread "main" software.amazon.smithy.java.core.serde.SerializationException: Unexpected Content-Type 'application/json; charset=utf-8' for protocol software.amazon.smithy.java.json.JsonCodec@6f36cf07
This is the code validates that the content-type matches expected payload media type for deserialization.
// Validate the media-type matches the codec.
In case of `awsRestJson1` this is `application/json`.  ( which isn't equal to `application/json; charset=utf-8`)

title: @Features.* annotations don't generate module name (m) field in feature-metadata.properties
stack_trace: * Helidon SE or Helidon MP: Helidon SE

The `@Features.*` annotations (`@Features.Name`, `@Features.Path`, `@Features.Description`, `@Features.Flavor`, `@Features.Preview`) do not generate the required `m` (module name) field in `META-INF/helidon/feature-metadata.properties`.

title: AOT processing fails when using `hibernate.hbm2ddl.auto=update`
stack_trace: When using **Spring Boot 4.0.1** with GraalVM native image compilation (AOT processing), configuring Hibernate's `hbm2ddl.auto=update` triggers a fatal error during the `processAot` Gradle task. The error occurs because Hibernate attempts to access a JDBC connection during AOT processing (for schema migration) but no connection is available at this stage.
- GraalVM: Any version (reproducible with latest GraalVM CE 21/25)
1. Create a new Spring Boot 4.0.1 project with Spring Data JPA dependency.
3. Add a simple JPA entity and repository (e.g., `User` entity + `UserRepository`).
4. Run GraalVM AOT processing via Gradle: `./gradlew processAot` (or build native image with `./gradlew nativeCompile`).
AOT processing completes successfully, and the native image can be built without errors.

The `processAot` task fails with an `AotProcessingException` caused by a Hibernate `PersistenceException` (**"Unable to build Hibernate SessionFactory"**) and a root cause of **"The application must supply JDBC connections"**.

Exception in thread "main" org.springframework.beans.factory.aot.AotProcessingException: Error executing 'org.springframework.beans.factory.aot.BeanRegistrationsAotProcessor': Unable to build Hibernate SessionFactory  [persistence unit: AotMetamodel]
Caused by: jakarta.persistence.PersistenceException: Unable to build Hibernate SessionFactory  [persistence unit: AotMetamodel]
Caused by: java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException: The application must supply JDBC connections
Adding the following Gradle configuration to disable schema generation during AOT processing resolves the issue:

During AOT processing, Spring Data JPA attempts to initialize a Hibernate `SessionFactory` for metamodel generation. When `hibernate.hbm2ddl.auto=update` is set, Hibernate tries to connect to the database to perform schema migration—but no JDBC connection is available in the AOT processing context (this is a build-time step, not runtime).

The workaround disables schema generation **only during AOT processing** by setting `jakarta.persistence.schema-generation.database.action=none`, which prevents Hibernate from attempting a database connection during build time.
- Fix Spring Boot 4.0.1 to handle `hibernate.hbm2ddl.auto=update` gracefully during AOT processing (without requiring manual task configuration).
- Automatically disable Hibernate schema generation during AOT processing (or provide a built-in property to control this behavior).
- Update Spring Boot documentation to note this limitation/workaround for GraalVM + Hibernate users.

This issue is specific to Spring Boot 4.0.1 (and possibly 4.0.x) – earlier versions (e.g., 3.2.x) may not exhibit this behavior due to differences in AOT processing for JPA. The workaround is functional but non-intuitive for users migrating to Spring Boot 4.0.x with GraalVM.

title: assets MUST NOT be loaded in static code
stack_trace: There are issues when loading asses in static code as that is exposed to a race condition. Loading assets with SkinLoader must not happen before class Klooni is initiated. In other cases Gdx.graphics will be null.  It happens that this condition is accidently met for the current state of the code.

The order classes are loaded and initialized is subject to the class loader involved and that may change in the future, especially as this is an Android app and Google is experimenting much with it's runtime.
There are more reason to not load assets in static code, ie. error handling and the like.
Example of issues (initiate effects in static code from class Klooni):

title: MetricsHub failed to start on Windows due to a non-writable log directory
stack_trace: Running `MetricsHubServiceManager.exe` on Windows fails with a `NoClassDefFoundError` caused by the application attempting to write logs into a non-writable directory under `C:\Program Files\MetricsHub`. When this directory cannot be written to, the application does not fall back to the user’s `LOCALAPPDATA` path as expected.
1. Install MetricsHub on Windows using the generated installer.
3. Observe the application failing to start.
If the default log directory under the installation path is not writable, MetricsHub should automatically fall back to using the user’s `LOCALAPPDATA` directory for log storage and start normally.
The application attempts to use a non-writable log directory, fails to initialize logging, and exits with an exception before starting.

title: Superinterfaces not kept anymore when class is referenced through annotation
stack_trace: Version: ProGuard 7.8.1 (earlier versions are not affected)
When a class implements an interface, and is referenced only through an annotation, then ProGuard does not preserve this superinterface information anymore.
So when an application then retrieves the class from the annotation and tries to create an instance, it might encounter an exception because the class does not implement the interface anymore.
Note: This originally occurred in the integration tests for Gson, see https://github.com/google/gson/actions/runs/19046171147/job/54394818198?pr=2934. The example below is a simplified version.
public static void main(String... args) throws Exception {
throw new Exception(obj.getClass() + " does not implement " + MyInterface.class);
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.Exception: class b does not implement interface c

Since this started occurring in ProGuard 7.8.1, I assume it is related to https://github.com/Guardsquare/proguard/commit/6dfd878ebb7c4c5b417fbff6cc7f5f84e6d41147. Maybe the reason for this is that while `InterfaceUsageMarker` has been moved up, the `AnnotationUsageMarker` usage was kept at its old position.
This is only a guess though, maybe the root cause is a different one. And maybe other `...UsageMarker` (unrelated to annotations) also have to run at an earlier stage?

title: Conflict when using tzatziki-spring-jpa and tzatziki-spring-mongodb in the same project
stack_trace: When using both tzatziki JPA/MongoDB dependencies inside the same projects, we get the following error:

Exception in thread "main" io.cucumber.core.runner.DuplicateStepDefinitionException: Duplicate step definitions in com.decathlon.tzatziki.steps.SpringMongoSteps.the_repository_contains_nothing(com.decathlon.tzatziki.utils.Guard,java.lang.reflect.Type) and com.decathlon.tzatziki.steps.SpringJPASteps.the_repository_contains_nothing(com.decathlon.tzatziki.utils.Guard,java.lang.reflect.Type)
A workaround is to remove the **Given** and **Then** annotations of the following methods in SpringMongoSteps.

I personally do not use repository/entities terms when using MongoDB, I prefer the notion of document and that change thus does not impact me. I don't know if that reasoning is shared with the majority of developers.
//@Given(THAT + GUARD + "the " + TYPE + " repository will contain" + INSERTION_MODE + ":$")
public void the_repository_will_contain(Guard guard, Type repositoryType, InsertionMode insertionMode, Object content) {
public void the_repository_contains(Guard guard, Type type, Comparison comparison, Object content) {
public void the_repository_contains_nothing(Guard guard, Type type) {
//@Given(THAT + GUARD + "the " + TYPE + " entities will contain" + INSERTION_MODE + ":$")
public void the_entities_will_contain(Guard guard, Type type, InsertionMode insertionMode, Object content) {
public void the_entities_contain(Guard guard, Type type, Comparison comparison, Object content) {
public void the_entities_contain_nothing(Guard guard, Type type) {

title: Context timeout report is not informative
stack_trace: ERROR , message: Timeout during execution of org.eclipse.rcptt.ctx.preferences.impl.PreferencesContextProcessor$1@17fff60

The problem here is that AdvancedInfo collected after the fact does not contain any information. This probably inidicates a busy UI thread, but does not help to isolate the problem. At the very least the error report should contain stack trace of UI thread.

We had similar issues with Workbench Context before, but those should were [fixed by properly handling UI thread exceptions in 2.7.1](https://github.com/eclipse-rcptt/org.eclipse.rcptt/commit/84af485c613eae959d945e166fa060366ece0f04#diff-e33431a96ea53dda254a9c8e73b3fd99e2000985b5ccb41e0d6ed6244995ac2e).

title: [7.0] Improve Parchment 404 error messages
stack_trace: The Parchment website suggests the following format on [their getting started page](<https://parchmentmc.org/docs/getting-started>) for FG5+: `2025.10.05-1.21.9`. Their site needs updating eventually for FG7 (the v prefix in the version badges is an added source of confusion), but a nice QoL feature would be to detect a legacy version format and show a more helpful error.
For example, when setting the mapping version to `2025.10.05-1.21.9`, it currently dumps this stacktrace:
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.RuntimeException: Failed to execute task `download[2025.10.05-1.21.9][parchment]` which is required by task `srg2names[parchment-2025.10.05-1.21.9]`
Caused by: java.lang.RuntimeException: Failed to execute task `download[2025.10.05-1.21.9][parchment]`
FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.
Having a problems report that suggests changing it to just "2025.10.05" without the "-1.21.9" suffix as a solution would be useful for those upgrading existing their existing FG6 setups.

title: (java): All requests hang indefinitely when ran on AWS Lambda for versions >= 2.2.0-rc3
stack_trace: Had some testing code which runs on AWS Lambda using the `java21` runtime on `x86_64`, noticed that bumping the version from 2.1.1 to 2.2.0 resulted in failures due to test timeouts despite any other changes.  Simple calls such as the following would have futures that never completed.
Enabling trace logging did not yield any meaningful log entries.
Futures are guaranteed to complete either successfully or exceptionally within the Java client.
1. Utilize the valkey-glide client in a Java program within AWS Lambda or any other environment where the glide client is loaded in a classloader other `ClassLoader.getSystemClassLoader()`
2. Attempt to make a call to any dataplane operation
3. Note that the future never completes
I was able to determine that the issue is throwing the following error (which is being ignored):
glide_rs::jni_client[0m[2m:[0m Unable to complete callback: Failed to find AsyncRegistry class: Java exception was thrown
Patching the related method that loads AsyncRegistry
Finally, patching my code to print out the classloader of the class itself:
reveals that lambda is running my code in a special classloader:

> Since Java 2 SDK release 1.2, when FindClass is called through the Invocation Interface, there is no current native method or its associated class loader. **In that case, the result of ClassLoader.getSystemClassLoader is used.** This is the class loader the virtual machine creates for applications, and is able to locate classes listed in the java.class.path property.

I believe that this is fundamentally because we wait to load the references to AsyncRegistry (and others) until we're attached in our own thread, which causes the `FindClass` jni method to use the system classloader.
I'll cut a PR with a proposed minimal fix.

title: Error trying to parse with weird named relation (case-sensitivity of keywords): CQLParseException: expected boolean, got '/'
stack_trace: The CQLParser throws an error which could be due to case-sensitivity when handling CQL keywords. I was testing on the example query in the [LOC CQL spec (section 12)](https://www.loc.gov/standards/sru/cql/spec.html) for the query `dc.TitlE Any/rEl.algOriThm=cori fish soRtbY Dc.TitlE`.

Both the [LOC](https://www.loc.gov/standards/sru/cql/spec.html) and [OASIS](https://docs.oasis-open.org/search-ws/searchRetrieve/v1.0/os/part5-cql/searchRetrieve-v1.0-os-part5-cql.html#_Toc324166800) specs mention case-insensitivity:
> All parts of CQL are case insensitive apart from user supplied search terms, values for modifiers and prefix map identifiers [...]
To reproduce the issue (at latest commit: 6251e96ce2434bb7cbe80e9ebeef70872e56f862):
String cql = "dc.TitlE Any/rEl.algOriThm=cori fish soRtbY Dc.TitlE";
Exception in thread "main" org.z3950.zing.cql.CQLParseException: expected boolean, got '/'
// line numbers might not align as I have inserted some debug statements...
While I was testing, I found that the following queries did parse differently (always as a `CQLTermNode`):
The query 1. did parse the `CQLTermNode` into `index`, `CQLRelation` ("any") and `term` ("fish").
The queries 2., 3. and 4. did parse into a `CQLTermNode` with only the `term` being filled as "dc.TitlE ANY fish"/... and default `index`/`relation`.
The queries 5. and 6. should probably also parse into a CQLTermNode with the `CQLRelation` of "other"/"Other". It currently put the full query into the `CQLTermNode.term`.
<!-- The BNF notes the `relation` with can be a `comparitor` → `namedComparitor` → `identifier` (which can be any string, even quoted?!). -->

The LOC CQL BNF would allow for relations to be any string (even quoted). The OASIS CQL ABNF is a bit more stricter while allowing any string, it doesn't allow quoting: `relation-modified` → `relation` → `relation-name` → `simple-name` → `simple-string` (so no special characters).
Is this behavior intended? Can it even be fixed (due to backwards compatibility)? It is probably not according to spec if I understand the BNFs.

Exception in thread "main" org.apache.fory.exception.SerializationException: java.lang.ClassCastException: class org.apache.fory.collection.CollectionSnapshot cannot be cast to class java.util.List (org.apache.fory.collection.CollectionSnapshot is in unnamed module of loader 'app'; java.util.List is in module java.base of loader 'bootstrap')

There seems to be a more fundamental issue with `CopyOnWriteArrayListSerializer` and how it works with codegen. For any object which has a `CopyOnWriteArrayList` field (like `CopyOnWriteArraySet`), serialization fails with the same error because the generated codec attempts to cast `CollectionSnapshot` to `List`.

title: `findByNameIn(List)` fails with `IllegalArgumentException` using EclipseLink
stack_trace: I've found out that with the new _spring-data-jpa_ major update (4.x) `findByInXXX` repository methods don't work with EclipseLink JPA vendor (they used to work with 3.5.9).

<summary>org.springframework.dao.InvalidDataAccessApiUsageException: You have attempted to set a value of type class java.util.ImmutableCollections$List12 for parameter 1 with expected type of class java.lang.String from query string SELECT ...</summary>

Exception in thread "main" org.springframework.dao.InvalidDataAccessApiUsageException: You have attempted to set a value of type class java.util.ImmutableCollections$List12 for parameter 1 with expected type of class java.lang.String from query string SELECT u FROM User u WHERE u.name IN (?1).

Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: You have attempted to set a value of type class java.util.ImmutableCollections$List12 for parameter 1 with expected type of class java.lang.String from query string SELECT u FROM User u WHERE u.name IN (?1).

Since they used to work with previous _spring-data-jpa_ major version (3.x), I'm posting it as a bug here. If it is an issue in EclipseLink which just pops up now it could be moved to EclipseLink issue tracker.

I'm attacing [springboot-eclipselink-findByInXXX.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/24492504/springboot-eclipselink-findByInXXX.zip) which is a minimal reproducer of the issue. It is a simple spring boot application with an application class `ReproducerApplication` and a repository `UserRepository` with `findByInXXX` method. It demonstrates:

* with _spring-data-jpa_ 3.5.9  and _eclipselink_ 4.0.9 - `findByInXXX` work (to start in that mode: comment `spring-boot.version` 4.0.1 and uncomment `spring-boot.version` 3.5.9 in _pom.xml,_ comment `Spring 4.x specific imports` and uncomment `Spring 3.x specific imports` in the _ReproducerApplication.java_)

title: [PE-D][Tester D] CLI crashes on invalid deposit amount input instead of showing an error message
stack_trace: 1. Launch the app and log in to any existing bank account.
App should display an error message such as:
> “Invalid amount format. Please enter a numeric value without symbols (e.g., 10000).”
Program crashes with an unhandled exception:
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: "$10000"
The CLI exits immediately, forcing the user to relaunch the app.
The app should **validate user input** and provide clear feedback instead of terminating.
A simple formatting mistake (e.g., including a `$` symbol) should not crash the program.
This indicates missing input validation and exception handling in the deposit feature.

title: [PE-D][Tester D] CLI crashes when withdrawing an amount larger than current balance instead of showing an error message
stack_trace: 1. Launch the app and log in to any existing bank account.
2. Enter a withdrawal command exceeding the available balance:
App should display an error message such as:
> “Insufficient balance. Please enter an amount less than or equal to your current balance.”
The app terminates with an uncaught exception:
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Balance cannot be negative
The CLI closes immediately, requiring the user to restart the application.
The app should gracefully handle invalid user inputs.
A withdrawal that exceeds the current balance is a common user error, and should **not** crash the program.
Proper input validation and exception handling are missing, severely affecting usability.

title: SparkDl4jMultiLayer: LimitedContextPool - Can't allocate new context OR cudaStreamSynchronize failed
stack_trace: I'm creating this issue as per @raver119's request
I'm experiencing a strange issue when using the `org.deeplearning4j.spark.impl.multilayer.SparkDl4jMultiLayer`

I'm training on a spark cluster with 8 slaves (all GPU machines with each 4 GPUs -- type Nvidia Tesla p40 with 24gb each). Training and testing works fine till epoch 30. In epoch 31 training goes fine, but when testing starts (using `org.deeplearning4j.spark.impl.multilayer.SparkDl4jMultiLayer.doEvaluation(org.apache.spark.api.java.JavaRDD<org.nd4j.linalg.dataset.DataSet>, int, int, T...)`) the whole process freezes (it doesn't crash, it simply hangs, without any failing spark tasks)
The logs of all the slaves keep printing this message over and over:
29 Mar 2019;09:11:28.442 [Executor task launch worker for task 19812] WARN  o.n.j.a.c.impl.LimitedContextPool - Can't allocate new context, sleeping...
The spark-submit command I'm using to launch the training is as follows (I'm hiding the `accountName` and `accountKey`for obvious reasons:

nohup /opt/spark-2.3.2-bin-hadoop2.7/bin/spark-submit --master spark://12.0.0.4:7077 --class org.daanvdn.sandbox.spark.SparkTrainerCli --driver-memory 400G --executor-memory 400G --executor-cores 4 --conf '-Dorg.bytedeco.javacpp.maxbytes=96G -Djava.io.tmpdir=/mnt/tmp' --conf 'spark.driver.extraJavaOptions=-Dorg.bytedeco.javacpp.maxbytes=96G -Djava.io.tmpdir=/mnt/tmp' /home/my-host/sparkjars/dl4j-azure-spark-1.0.0-SNAPSHOT-bin.jar -epochs 100 -batch 128 -avg 2 -prefetch 1 -container some-container -trainFolder train -testFolder test -evalMode ALL_EPOCHS -rddTrainingApproach Export -train true -evalNumWorkers 1 -accountName #### -accountKey #### | tee nohup.out
As far as spark-configuration is concerned, my setup is as follows:
2) `spark-env.sh` has `SPARK_WORKER_INSTANCES=1` so I'm actually only using 1 of the GPUs per machine.
Even after waiting for a couple of hours, the slaves keep hanging, so there is no other option than to kill the process.
When I rerun the experiment, the same happens over and over: the application always freezes in the evaluation phase of epoch 31.

I've uploaded the code I'm running to [GitHub](https://github.com/daanvdn/dl4j-azure-minimal-example).  The main class is <https://github.com/daanvdn/dl4j-azure-minimal-example/blob/master/dl4j-azure-spark/src/main/java/org/daanvdn/sandbox/spark/SparkTrainerCli.java>. The `MultiLayerConfiguration` is added as a java [resource](https://github.com/daanvdn/dl4j-azure-minimal-example/blob/master/dl4j-azure-spark/src/main/resources/org/daanvdn/sandbox/spark/cnnGlobalPooling_var_lRate.json)
In an attempt to fix this freezing problem, I played around with some spark settings, most importantly `SPARK_WORKER_INSTANCES` and `executor-cores`.

I have tried changing the value of `SPARK_WORKER_INSTANCES` to `4` and set `executor-cores` also to `4` so that each slave uses 4 GPUs instead of 1. This needs to happen anyway, because there is no reason not to use all GPUs of the slaves.

When applying these changes the original problem of freezing goes away. However, this in turn causes the application to crash (rather than hang). An error message that is always printed in this situation is `cudaStreamSynchronize(...) failed` as below:
2019-04-02 10:06:49 ERROR SparkUncaughtExceptionHandler:91 - Uncaught exception in thread Thread[ADSI prefetch thread,5,main]
Caused by: java.lang.RuntimeException: Error loading DataSet
This `cudaStreamSynchronize(...) failed` error message is always preceded by one of two errors/warnings:

1) it can be preceded by a warning  `ConvolutionLayer:347 - CuDNN execution failed - falling back on built-in implementation` as below (cf. [link](https://github.com/daanvdn/dl4j-azure-minimal-example/blob/master/cudnn.log)):
2019-04-02 10:06:49 WARN  ConvolutionLayer:347 - CuDNN execution failed - falling back on built-in implementation
2019-04-02 10:06:49 ERROR Executor:91 - Exception in task 59.0 in stage 21.0 (TID 1175)

2) it can also be preceded by the error message `Out of [DEVICE] memory, host memory will be used instead` like here (cf [link](https://github.com/daanvdn/dl4j-azure-minimal-example/blob/master/OUT_OF_DEVICE_MEMORY.log)):
2019-04-02 10:06:49 WARN  CudaZeroHandler:339 - Out of [DEVICE] memory, host memory will be used instead: deviceId: [3], requested bytes: [4]
2019-04-02 10:06:49 ERROR SparkUncaughtExceptionHandler:91 - Uncaught exception in thread Thread[UniGC thread 3,5,main]
2019-04-02 10:06:49 ERROR SparkUncaughtExceptionHandler:91 - Uncaught exception in thread Thread[UniGC thread 2,5,main]
2019-04-02 10:06:49 ERROR SparkUncaughtExceptionHandler:91 - Uncaught exception in thread Thread[UniGC thread 1,5,main]

Regarding this `Out of [DEVICE] memory` error, I am puzzled. I don't understand why the GPU would go OOM: when I monitor the GPU memory usage with `nvidia-smi` it never goes above 1gb per GPU. Even though every GPU has 24gb, the GPU still crashes. I've made a [screen recording](https://github.com/daanvdn/dl4j-azure-minimal-example/blob/master/nvidia_smi_recording.mp4) of the `nvidia-smi` monitoring for one of the slaves: . From minute 4 onwards you can see that even though it's using about 1gb of memory, the process associated with the GPUs crashes and nvidi-smi reports `no running process found`. After a couple of seconds a new process is spawned and gets associated with the GPUs. This new process runs until about 9m 50s and the same happens again: GPU memory usage is about 1gb, the process crashes, a new process is created and attached to the GPUs and so on. I've also played around with the `--executor-memory` and tried values between 100gb and 400gb but this has no influence.

As a final important remark it should be noted that when I run the same code but with `-evalMode` set to `NEVER`  (keeping  `SPARK_WORKER_INSTANCES=4` and `--executor-cores 4` ) no crashing or freezing is happening. In other words: if I only call `org.deeplearning4j.spark.impl.multilayer.SparkDl4jMultiLayer.fit(java.lang.String)` there is no problem. As soon as I start to do evaluation by calling `SparkDl4jMultiLayer#doEvaluation`, the thing crashes.
With regard to the evaluation, I also tried to play around with the setting of `evalNumWorkers` (using any value from `1` to `4`) but this has no effect.

As for the data that I'm training on, this is hosted on Azure in a Block Blob Storage container. I've added two zipped folders to this git repo with a sample of my [train](https://github.com/daanvdn/dl4j-azure-minimal-example/blob/master/sample_train.7z) and [test](https://github.com/daanvdn/dl4j-azure-minimal-example/blob/master/sample_test.7z) data.
- cluster of 8 slave machines, 1 driver machine
- every machine is hosted in Azure and has:

title: Exception in Jimple Body Creation with original names: IllegalStateException: UnitThrowAnalysis StmtSwitch: type of throw argument is not a RefType!
stack_trace: When reading from an APK, turning on the option "use-original-names" for the jimple body phase causes crashes in about 50% of the apps that I have tried.
To reproduce the problem I created a test project
To cause the crash, run `./gradlew test --debug`
The offending apk is in the directory `src/test/resources/us.koller.cameraroll_36.apk` of the project.
The phase option for original names is required to trigger the bug:
java.lang.IllegalStateException: UnitThrowAnalysis StmtSwitch: type of throw argument is not a RefType!
Exception in thread "Thread-6" java.lang.IllegalStateException: UnitThrowAnalysis StmtSwitch: type of throw argument is not a RefType!

It appears that the parameter register p1 is reused in the Dalvik bytecode.  First, it is an integer parameter and then it gets an InflateException assigned. This pattern appears in a large number of applications I have tried.
The method in question can be seen in smali here:
The register $u3 is assumed to have the type int but is then thrown.

title: AOT Processing Fails with NoClassDefFoundError for Apache HttpClient 4.x Classes
stack_trace: # AOT Processing Fails with NoClassDefFoundError for Apache HttpClient 4.x Classes
- **Spring Data Elasticsearch**: (version bundled with Spring Boot 4.0.0)
When upgrading to Spring Boot 4.0.0 and running AOT processing (`processAot` task), the build fails with `NoClassDefFoundError` for Apache HttpClient 4.x classes.
The issue originates from `ElasticsearchClientRuntimeHints.java` at line 46, which attempts to register Apache HttpClient 4.x classes for serialization:
However, **Elasticsearch Java Client 8.x has migrated from Apache HttpClient 4.x to HttpClient 5.x**, which uses different package names:
AOT processing should complete successfully without requiring Apache HttpClient 4.x classes.
AOT processing fails with `NoClassDefFoundError` because the referenced classes no longer exist in the classpath.

title: Spring Boot 4.0.0 / Spring Cloud Function 5.0.0 (GCP Adapter) fails with `unknown protocol: nested` on deployment
stack_trace: After upgrading our application from `Spring Boot 3.5.8` to `4.0.0` and `Spring Cloud Function 4.3.0` to `5.0.0`, the deployment of our Spring Cloud Function using the `spring-cloud-function-adapter-gcp` fails immediately upon initialisation within the Google Cloud Functions (GCF) environment. The function continues to run perfectly fine locally using the Function Maven plugin.

The failure occurs during the construction of the GCF Adapter class, which is unable to resolve resources within the executable JAR's nested dependencies, leading to a `MalformedURLException: unknown protocol: nested` root cause message. The error seems to indicate that the GCF Invoker's classloader is initialized without the custom nested URL protocol handler required to unpack dependencies from the standard Spring Boot executable JAR format. I'm assuming the issue is related to Spring dropping the classic uber-jar loader support in the latest release?
"Exception in thread "main" java.lang.RuntimeException: Could not construct an instance of org.springframework.cloud.function.adapter.gcp.GcfJarLauncher: java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: java.net.MalformedURLException: unknown protocol: nested
Caused by: java.net.MalformedURLException: unknown protocol: nested

Further testing revealed that explicitly restoring the `spring-cloud-function-adapter-gcp` to `4.3.0` **and** the `spring-boot-maven-plugin` to version `3.5.8`, while keeping the rest of the application dependencies on the Spring Boot 4.x line, fixed the issue for me.
This all is largely unknown territory for me, but I thought this was worth reporting anyway. I can't easily share an MRE currently, but happy to provide any more details where possible 👍.

title: UnsupportedOperationException: third-party implementation of CancellableContinuation when using Kotlin coroutines with New Relic Java agent
stack_trace: [NOTE]: # ( ^^ Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above. ^^ )
When running a Kotlin coroutine–based application with the New Relic Java agent (v8.25.0) attached, the process throws an exception inside a coroutine `delay()` call:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException: third-party implementation of CancellableContinuation is not supported
The exception occurs only when the agent is active (`-javaagent:/newrelic/newrelic-agent.jar`).
If the agent is removed, the coroutine executes normally without any errors.

It seems that the agent’s bytecode instrumentation wraps or modifies the coroutine continuation classes, causing the kotlinx.coroutines runtime to detect a “third-party implementation” and throw this `UnsupportedOperationException`.
[NOTE]: # ( Tell us what you expected to happen. )
Coroutines should operate normally with the New Relic Java agent attached.
[NOTE]: # ( Provide any other relevant log data. )
[TIP]:  # ( Scrub logs and diagnostic information for sensitive information )
com.newrelic INFO: Using default collector host: collector.newrelic.com
third-party implementation of CancellableContinuation is not supported
When the same build runs **without** the agent, this exception does not appear.
[NOTE]: # ( Please be as specific as possible. )
[TIP]:  # ( Link a sample application that demonstrates the issue. )
1. Create a minimal Kotlin application with `kotlinx-coroutines-core:1.9.0`.
4. Observe that the application fails with `UnsupportedOperationException` during the first `delay()` call.

[TIP]:  # ( Include as many relevant details about your environment as possible including the running version of New Relic software, JVM vendor and version, framework versions, and any relevant configuration. )
[TIP]:  # ( Add any other context about the problem here. For example, relevant community posts or support tickets. )
This appears to originate from a defensive check inside `kotlinx.coroutines.CancellableContinuationKt.invokeOnCancellation()`,
which throws when the continuation is not a `CancellableContinuationImpl`.
That method is defined here in Kotlin’s source:
The issue seems related to instrumentation changes introduced around  https://github.com/newrelic/newrelic-java-agent/pull/2454
Downgrading the New Relic Java agent from `8.25.0` to `8.24.0` resolves the issue.
With version 8.24.0, coroutine `delay()` and other suspension functions operate normally.

title: [PE-D][Tester B] Editing data file to invalid rating causes crash
stack_trace: If the persisted data file contains an out-of-range rating (e.g., 6), the app attempts to construct a Rating directly during deserialization, which throws an unchecked IllegalArgumentException. This can crash the load path instead of reporting a validation error or recovering gracefully as suggested by the User Guide.
Run the app once to generate data/foodtrail.json.
Open data/foodtrail.json and set any restaurant’s "rating" to 6 (or -1).
The app should detect invalid data and handle it gracefully:
Either reject only the invalid entry and continue, or
Reset to empty data with a clear message, consistent with the User Guide’s guidance on invalid data files.
App does not start up at all. The following exception is unhandled:
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.RuntimeException: Exception in Application init method
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Rating must be an integer between 0 and 5 (inclusive).
Wrap new `Rating(rating)` in a try/catch and rethrow as `IllegalValueException` with `Rating.MESSAGE_CONSTRAINTS`, or
Validate the integer bound first and create `Optional.empty()` or fail gracefully with a handled exception.
Ensure the upper-level storage loader catches `IllegalValueException` and follows the UG behavior (e.g., reset data and continue running with a clear error message).

title: [PE-D][Tester B] Application crashes when image resource is missing
stack_trace: The application crashes with a `NullPointerException` when image resources are missing from the JAR file. This occurs during application startup when trying to load the application icon.

When `getResourceAsStream()` returns `null` (resource not found), the null value is passed directly to the `Image` constructor without validation, causing a `NullPointerException` and application crash.
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.RuntimeException: Exception in Application start method
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException: Input stream must not be null
The application should handle missing image resources gracefully by:
1. Checking if the resource stream is null before creating the Image
3. Either using a default/fallback image or continuing without the icon
- **User Experience**: Application fails to start, preventing users from using the application
- **Frequency**: Occurs when image resources are missing (rare but possible during deployment or JAR packaging issues)
Add null check before creating Image:
return null; // or return a default image
The same issue exists in `src/main/java/seedu/address/commons/util/AppUtil.java:16-18` with the `getImage()` method.
This bug was discovered during code review. The same pattern should be fixed in `AppUtil.getImage()` as well.

title: [PE-D][Tester E] Application crashes on EOF instead of exiting gracefully
stack_trace: When standard input reaches EOF (e.g., during piped input or redirected commands), the application crashes with a `NoSuchElementException`. This occurs after valid command execution, such as `help`, when the input stream ends.
This behaviour breaks expected CLI conventions — most command-line tools terminate cleanly after EOF, without stack traces or uncaught exceptions.
2. After EOF is reached, the application crashes with an exception
The application should exit gracefully once the end of the input stream is reached (EOF).
The application crashes with `java.util.NoSuchElementException: No line found` exception at line `SGSafe.java:41`:
Exception in thread "main" java.util.NoSuchElementException: No line found
This crash occurs in production-relevant scenarios such as:
- Automating CLI usage with shell scripts

The unhandled exception produces confusing output for users and can be misinterpreted as a fatal error. It also violates the expected robustness of CLI tools, which should terminate gracefully on EOF.

title: [BUG] MCP registry fails to parse official registry sample (misnamed json property)
stack_trace: <!-- Please provide as many details as possible, this will help us to deliver a fix as soon as possible. Thank you! -->
MCP registry fails to parse official registry sample (misnamed json property)
MCP Registry deserialisation error. Unrecognised property exception while deserializing MCP registry entries.

As per the spec (and examples) the property names are isRepeated, IsRequired for packageArguments and runtimeArguments. The corresponding McpRuntimeArgument class has a isRepeated() getter and isRepeated private field. This doesn't seem to be treated as property 'isRepeated', instead property name is just "repeated".
Was able to confirm this by dumping the property names as Jackson sees it.
Currently it fails to parse examples in official mcp registry repo.

Exception in thread "main" com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.exc.UnrecognizedPropertyException: Unrecognized field "isRepeated" (class dev.langchain4j.mcp.registryclient.model.McpRuntimeArgument), not marked as ignorable (9 known properties: "value", "choices", "format", "valueHint", "type", "name", "description", "default", "variables"])

at [Source: REDACTED (`StreamReadFeature.INCLUDE_SOURCE_IN_LOCATION` disabled); line: 30, column: 29] (through reference chain: dev.langchain4j.mcp.registryclient.model.McpServer["packages"]->java.util.ArrayList[0]->dev.langchain4j.mcp.registryclient.model.McpPackage["runtimeArguments"]->java.util.ArrayList[1]->dev.langchain4j.mcp.registryclient.model.McpRuntimeArgument["isRepeated"])
It should be compliant with the official spec and parse the registry entries without errors.
- LangChain4j version: 1.8.0 (also tested with previous versions)
<!-- Add any other context about the problem here. -->
Adding a  ` @JsonProperty("isRepeated")` to the getter should likely fix it - not sure about other implications on alias.

title: [PE-D][Tester D] Corrupted data files causes total system failure
stack_trace: _NOTE: this defect is distinct from a very similarly named defect. This defect is **SIGNIFICANTLY WORSE**._
When a data file is corrupted in a very particular manner, attempts to start the program will cause an instant crash and exit without any indication to the user.
1. Start with the base data set.
2. Add a feeding session: `feed f/Alex Yeoh n/Max dt/2020-10-10 10:00`
4. Edit `data/addressbook.json` in this manner: change the feeding session `dateTime` field to `0000` (or any invalid input).
Actual behaviour: instant system crash (silent; only logged in console).
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.RuntimeException: Exception in Application init method
Caused by: java.time.format.DateTimeParseException: Text '0000' could not be parsed at index 4
**Program will refuse to start on any further attempt unless the data file is completely deleted or the error is fixed manually.**
Expected: Any sane error handling/attempt at recovery for corrupt data files.
High. Very high hindrance: unable to use the app at all on this failure. User has to manually debug this.
As an advertised feature (editing data file), some graceful error handling is expected. Probably just a missed edge case, since other failed edits still allow the program to start up.

title: [JENKINS-50199] Failed pipeline jobs stuck running after incorrect resume
stack_trace: <!-- ### Imported Jira references for easier searching -->
"Do not allow the pipeline to resume if the master restarts": Enabled on all jobs

I logged into a Jenkins master and saw no builds running but there was a queue of about 10 jobs. When mousing over the queued jobs, I saw "pending - Already running 2 builds across all nodes". This is strange because no jobs were showing as running and no Jenkins agents or executors were showing any running builds.

I then ran "http://xx.xxx.xxx.xxx:8080/computer/api/xml?tree=computer[executors[currentExecutable[url]],oneOffExecutors[currentExecutable[url]]]&xpath=//url&wrapper=builds" which did show 5 builds were running. I checked these builds and they were red (failure) and were not running.
I checked the console log of a build that showed as running but isn't and saw the line below near the top of the log.
Resume disabled by user, switching to high-performance, low-durability mode.
At the end of the of the log I saw the following:
Resuming build at Tue Mar 13 23:04:52 UTC 2018 after Jenkins restart
Why did the build try to resume almost a day later? The job and system durability are configured to not resume builds. Below are some details taken from the API for the build.
I checked the Java process on the server and it was last restarted on March 02 2018.
What triggered the "Jenkins restart" identified on Mar 13 23:04:52 UTC 2018 since the Java process was not restarted?
Why does this get the build stuck in a "running" state when it's not running?

This issue can be seen across many of our Jenkins masters. In each case we see "Resuming build at xxxxx after Jenkins restart" occur a few days after the build failure or abort even though Java was not restarted. This issue didn't occur on Jenkins 2.60.3 running the older (pre-durability configurable) Pipeline plugins.
I checked the jenkins.log file and saw the following when the build was attempting to be resumed.
WARNING: Pipeline state not properly persisted, cannot resume job/JENKINS-JOB-NAME1/42/
WARNING: Unexpected exception in CPS VM thread: CpsFlowExecution[OwnerJENKINS-JOB-NAME1/42:JENKINS-JOB-NAME1 #42]
WARNING: Unexpected exception in CPS VM thread: CpsFlowExecution[OwnerJENKINS-JOB-NAME1/42:JENKINS-JOB-NAME1 #42]
WARNING: Pipeline state not properly persisted, cannot resume job/JENKINS-JOB-NAME1/40/
WARNING: Unexpected exception in CPS VM thread: CpsFlowExecution[OwnerJENKINS-JOB-NAME1/40:JENKINS-JOB-NAME1 #40]
WARNING: Unexpected exception in CPS VM thread: CpsFlowExecution[OwnerJENKINS-JOB-NAME1/40:JENKINS-JOB-NAME1 #40]
WARNING: Pipeline state not properly persisted, cannot resume job/JENKINS-JOB-NAME2/41/
WARNING: Unexpected exception in CPS VM thread: CpsFlowExecution[OwnerJENKINS-JOB-NAME2/41:JENKINS-JOB-NAME2 #41]
WARNING: Unexpected exception in CPS VM thread: CpsFlowExecution[OwnerJENKINS-JOB-NAME2/41:JENKINS-JOB-NAME2 #41]

I only saw WorkflowRun.copyLogs with workflow in the name in a thread dump so I'm not sure if it is related. I didn't see anything BLOCKING. A lot of different items were WAITING on "java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject".
Running the Jenkins script below will set the running build to aborted to work around the issue.

title: Can't deploy an instance of Sleeper
stack_trace: Sleeper won't deploy, because when the CDK app looks up the version ID of the S3 object for a lambda jar, it does not correctly include the version number in the filename. The version number is read from the instance property before the CDK sets that instance property, so the CDK looks for jars with a version number of "null".
It seems like this problem was introduced in the following PR:
The `scripts/deploy/deployNew.sh` script also fails because of "changeme" values in the template.
1. Run `scripts/deploy/deployNew.sh` without editing the template first
The script should deploy an instance with default settings if you haven't changed the template.
All the properties that have default values should be unset in the template (as described in https://github.com/gchq/sleeper/issues/6128).
We can add an integration test to assert that the version number is included in the filename of a jar when the instance property is set after the SleeperJarsInBucket object is created.
We can add unit tests to assert that all the properties with default values are unset, and do not have values in the template file.

title: BluezonerIdGenerator::createBluezonerId is plainly wrong
stack_trace: At first, I want to add this as a comment to either #2 or #5,
But, after some thought, I think this issue is different from both of them.
The Id generation is plainly wrong in those steps:

- https://github.com/BluezoneGlobal/react-native-bluetooth-scan/blob/d9ee70fd594093a30e50b6e62a7593a8397c2dab/lib/android/src/main/java/com/scan/BluezonerIdGenerator.java#L30 have you thought the consequence of the event `rand.nextLong()` returns `java.lang.Long.MIN_VALUE`? `Math.abs(java.lang.Long.MIN_VALUE)` will return `java.lang.Long.MIN_VALUE`, thus https://github.com/BluezoneGlobal/react-native-bluetooth-scan/blob/d9ee70fd594093a30e50b6e62a7593a8397c2dab/lib/android/src/main/java/com/scan/BluezonerIdGenerator.java#L33 will return (most likely) negative number, thus https://github.com/BluezoneGlobal/react-native-bluetooth-scan/blob/d9ee70fd594093a30e50b6e62a7593a8397c2dab/lib/android/src/main/java/com/scan/BluezonerIdGenerator.java#L36 will throw unchecked exception `StringIndexOutOfBoundsException`
$ cat BluezonerIdGenerator.java && javac BluezonerIdGenerator.java && java BluezonerIdGenerator
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: String index out of range: -8

- Next, even if `Random.nextLong()` doesn't return `Long.MIN_VALUE`, https://github.com/BluezoneGlobal/react-native-bluetooth-scan/blob/d9ee70fd594093a30e50b6e62a7593a8397c2dab/lib/android/src/main/java/com/scan/BluezonerIdGenerator.java#L30 causes the first bias to non-zero value, all non-zero values have a slightly higher priority to zero, (0 will be made from 0 only, 1 will be made from -1 and 1, and so on, etc...)

- https://github.com/BluezoneGlobal/react-native-bluetooth-scan/blob/d9ee70fd594093a30e50b6e62a7593a8397c2dab/lib/android/src/main/java/com/scan/BluezonerIdGenerator.java#L33 creates more bias toward near index-0, this is discussed in #5, albeit, Huan only discussed about iOS.
- 2020-04-28T22:15:12: Correct LOC of `String::substring` and Exception's name.

title: Cancelled async `java.net.http.HttpRequest` does not complete exceptionally when agent is present
stack_trace: This re-opens a previous issue [Cancellation of async java.net.http.HttpRequest no longer works when agent is present](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-java-instrumentation/issues/14696).

The fix applied in response to the previous issue does not fully work, as the `.exceptionally(ex -> "** cancelled **")` is somehow ignored. This causes applications awaiting completion of the future (either normally or exceptionally) to hang if the request was cancelled.
The following should be printed to the terminal:
Request was cancelled with java.util.concurrent.CancellationException: Request cancelled
The following is printed to the terminal:
Request was cancelled with java.util.concurrent.CancellationException: Request cancelled

Note the lack of output `Got response: ** cancelled **`, which would seem to imply the future does not complete exceptionally, which is contrary to the output `Request was cancelled with java.util.concurrent.CancellationException: Request cancelled`. I don't understand why this is happening. Is there some confusion with the wrapped futures?
As before, the application behaves as expected if the agent is not present. This demonstrates that the presence of the agent changes the application behaviour.

title: [Java] Custom enum as Map key fails with XLANG despite registration
stack_trace: - [x] I had searched in the [issues](https://github.com/apache/fury/issues) and found no similar issues.
### What did you expect to see?
I expected the serialization and deserialization to complete successfully since I explicitly registered both Kind enum class and SomeClass using fury.register().
I received the following exception indicating that the class is not registered, despite having registered it:

Exception in thread "main" org.apache.fury.exception.InsecureException: class org.apache.fury.Main$Kind is not registered, please check whether it's the type you want to serialize or a **vulnerability**. If safe, you should invoke `Fury#register` to register class, which will have better performance by skipping classname serialization. If your env is 100% secure, you can also avoid this exception by disabling class registration check using `FuryBuilder#requireClassRegistration(false)`
I found that the error occurs in AbstractMapSerializer.java at line 469 where it's trying to get the serializer for the map key:

I've verified that when using standard Java types (like String) as Map keys with the same configuration, it works correctly. The issue seems specific to using custom enum types as Map keys in XLANG mode, despite proper registration.

I've searched through existing issues but couldn't find any addressing this specific problem. Is there a limitation with custom enum types as Map keys in XLANG mode, or am I missing something in my registration process?

title: [BUG] OkHttpFluxRequestBody does not correctly propagate IOExceptions
stack_trace: We are seeing unhandled exception logs when a `java.net.SocketException` occurs during connection creation.

I believe the issues is that [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/blob/19b07befe4080f7a0a3a03dc13bb12f43bd7240e/sdk/core/azure-core-http-okhttp/src/main/java/com/azure/core/http/okhttp/implementation/OkHttpFluxRequestBody.java#L92-L94) in the implementation of the okhttp `RequestBody` it is expected to throw an `IOException`.

There are various points in the stack trace where okhttp can gracefully handle `IOExceptions`, see for example the [RetryAndFollowUpInterceptor](https://github.com/square/okhttp/blob/c3f052fd9454bcc1f395346a92109e7be4282760/okhttp/src/commonJvmAndroid/kotlin/okhttp3/internal/http/RetryAndFollowUpInterceptor.kt#L76).
However, the custom `OkHttpFluxRequestBody` is propagating the SocketException wrapped in a `reactor.core.Exceptions$ReactiveException` so this is not handled correctly.
I would like to contribute a PR where the affected code path is wrapped in a try catch block and in case the ReactiveException is caused by an IOException then the IOException is thrown.
Exception in thread "OkHttp Dispatcher" reactor.core.Exceptions$ReactiveException: java.net.SocketException: Connection reset by peer
Caused by: java.net.SocketException: Connection reset by peer
The original IOException is propagated correctly
Kindly make sure that you have added all the following information above and checkoff the required fields otherwise we will treat the issuer as an incomplete report

title: node.name=${HOSTNAME} in the environment variable could not be resolved
stack_trace: I use the environment variable `node.name=$HOSTNAME` to dynamically set the node name.
It is fine until Elasticsearch version 7.17.7.
When I upgraded to 8.6.0, Elasticsearch failed to start.
The problem is `HOSTNAME` in the environment variable could not be resolved when starting up Elasticsearch.
The expected behavior is `$HOSTNAME` should be replaced by the hostname of the running Elasticsearch machine.
`docker-compose up es` will reproduce the problem.
`$${HOSTNAME}` is escaped and should be interpreted as `${HOSTNAME}` in Elasticsearch.
I checked that there is no problem with version 7.17.7 using the image `docker.elastic.co/elasticsearch/elasticsearch:7.17.7`.
I confirmed that the same problem occurs in AWS ECS.
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Could not resolve placeholder 'HOSTNAME'

title: Beans which contain @FixedRate that are vetoed from a CDI extension still trigger scheduling
stack_trace: **Description** In MicroProfile version 3.2.8, I observed that when a bean is programmatically vetoed using the `veto()` method in a CDI extension's `ProcessAnnotatedType` observer, and the vetoed bean includes the `@FixedRate` annotation, the scheduled task is still triggered, resulting in a `NullPointerException`:
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "jakarta.enterprise.inject.spi.Bean.getScope()" because "bean" is null

**Expected Behavior** Ideally, when a bean is programmatically vetoed, all its annotations, including `@FixedRate`, should be ignored. Therefore, I expect the `@FixedRate` invocation to be vetoed along with the rest of the bean.
1. Create a CDI extension that observes `ProcessAnnotatedType` events and vetoes a bean using the `veto()` method.
2. Define a bean with the `@FixedRate` annotation that is targeted by the vetoing extension.
3. Run the application and observe the `NullPointerException`.
