title: Blessed-bluez Incompatibility with BlueZ 5.82+:  "Method Get with signature "ss" on interface "org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties" doesn't exist
stack_trace: The `blessed-bluez` library (version 0.64) is incompatible with BlueZ versions 5.82 and potentially later versions. The library works correctly with BlueZ 5.66 but fails with BlueZ 5.82.
When running an application using `blessed-bluez` on Raspberry Pi 3B with BlueZ 5.82, the following error occurs during application initialization:

[DBusConnection [listener=false]] DEBUG org.freedesktop.dbus.connections.impl.DBusConnection -- Handling incoming error: Error(1,25) { Invalid=>null, Path=>null, Interface=>null, Member=>null, Error Name=>org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.UnknownMethod, Reply Serial=>6, Destination=>:1.31, Sender=>:1.2, Signature=>s, Unix FD=>null } { Method "Get" with signature "ss" on interface "org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties" doesn't exist
Error: Method "Get" with signature "ss" on interface "org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties" doesn't exist
org.freedesktop.dbus.errors.UnknownMethod: Method "Get" with signature "ss" on interface "org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties" doesn't exist
The same application works without any issues on systems running BlueZ 5.66.
The error indicates that the DBus `Properties` interface method signature has changed between BlueZ versions 5.66 and 5.82. Specifically:
- **Operating System**: Raspberry Pi OS (Debian-based) Debian Bookworm
- **Operating System**: Raspberry Pi OS (Debian-based) Debian Trixie
1. Raspberry Pi 3B with Raspberry Pi OS
4. BLE device (e.g., heart rate monitor, fitness tracker) discoverable nearby
Until this issue is fixed, use BlueZ version 5.66
- Application logs with full stack trace
- **Environment**: Raspberry Pi 3B, Raspberry Pi OS Trixie and Bookworm

The private method `extractValue` in the Java class `ContainerRegistryCredentialsPolicy` is not working properly when the container registry name contains one of the keywords: `service` or `scope`.

Name your container registry with word `service` or `scope` in the name, and try to list repository names using the SDK, you will receive the 401 Unauthorized exception above.
You can test it easily this way:
Actually, the issuing of the access token for the CR will be skipped, here is the code snippet of the method in the `ContainerRegistryCredentialsPolicy` class:
You can easily verify that extracting `WWW-Authenticate` response header is not working properly with the following example:
Test the private method `ContainerRegistryCredentialsPolicy.extractValue` and you'll make sure that `service` is null. So, in the above code snippet issuing access token will be skipped.
Authorization and issuing tokens for the CR is working properly regardless the container registry name.

title: Improve handling of JDA exceptions during startup
stack_trace: JDA performs checks when building interactions, e.g. that required options aren't added after non-required options. Currently we don't handle these exceptions at all. This makes it nearly impossible for the user to find the true cause of the exception.
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Cannot add required options after non-required options!
- Add error handling to the CommandTree
- log which command definition caused the exception
- shutdown JDA-Commands (and if enabled JDA) on exception
- revisit this problem for other interaction types and apply handling as well
- Reimplementing all JDA checks in JDA-Commands

title: [JENKINS-27669] Creating an empty logger crashs Jenkins
stack_trace: <!-- ### Imported Jira references for easier searching -->
With support bundle plugin installed, when I create a new logger and let the logger classname field empty, Jenkins crashes when I click Save button.
On save, Jenkins starts to write tons of exception logs and is not responsible anymore. Killing the JVM is the only way to stop it doing this.
On 1.580, faulty configuration is saved on disk. To restart the instance, faulty configuration file $JENKINS_HOME/log/.xml must be removed.
On 1.606, configuration is not saved, so restarting the instance works.
Originally reported by ydubreuil, imported from: Creating an empty logger crashs Jenkins
With support bundle plugin installed, when I create a new logger and let the logger classname field empty, Jenkins crashes when I click Save button.
On save, Jenkins starts to write tons of exception logs and is not responsible anymore. Killing the JVM is the only way to stop it doing this.
On 1.580, faulty configuration is saved on disk. To restart the instance, faulty configuration file $JENKINS_HOME/log/<faulty>.xml must be removed.
On 1.606, configuration is not saved, so restarting the instance works.
